Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AGNES. Algebraic Geometry NorthEastern Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
Algebraic geometry has a strong and broad representation at the research institutions of the Northeastern states. AGNES is a series of biannual workshops that intends to further the interaction and collaborations between the algebraic geometers in the area. Each workshop is held over a weekend at one of the participating institutions. The workshops include research talks by renowned experts and junior researchers, both from outside the area and within. Professional development sessions and introductory pre-talks are aimed particularly at graduate students. Every workshop culminates with an open problem session. This gives an opportunity to disseminate recent results and developments, and exchange ideas and views about future directions of algebraic geometry.

Algebraic geometry is the study of spaces defined by polynomial equations. Many of the spaces occurring in nature are of this type, and for this reason algebraic geometry has found diverse applications in the sciences. In particular, there are strong connections with recent work in theoretical physics (string theory). This grant will support a series of algebraic geometry conferences in the Northeastern states. The key aims of the series are to expose graduate students to a broad spectrum of research in the field and to improve communication between the many algebraic geometers in the northeast.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of AGNES workshops is to provide a regular forum for interaction among mathematicians from the Northeastern United States and beyond, whose interests relate to algebraic geometry.  The AGNES workshops take place twice per year at rotating locations, and they provide a venue in which mathematicians of different career levels and from geographically separate institutions can easily communicate.

The Fall 2011 AGNES workshop at Stony Brook University included 8 research talks over the course of 3 days. Several of the research talks were preceded by 'pre-talks' by the speakers aimed at students and junior participants, including background, history and context to make the research lecture more useful. There was a poster session where about 20 junior participants presented posters and discussed their work in small groups. We also held a professional development event about employment opportunities for mathematicians in the private sector, with a lecture by a former algebraic geometry professor about the transition to working for a hedge fund. The lectures were videorecorded, and those videos are freely available for download by all from the AGNES workshop webpage.  Our AGNES workshop was attended by more than 170 participants, a majority of them graduate students, from a spectrum of different types of institutions.  The AGNES workshop led to many one-on-one and small-group discussions between junior mathematicians and senior mathematicians.  Feedback gathered from the participants was very positive, with a number of useful suggestions for improving future meetings of AGNES.
